text: well I think this is a very difficult
situation for any politician the
catastrophe we experienced last week is
the biggest ever since Latin
independence and as prime minister said
he's taking and assuming the full
political and moral responsibility of
course after this catastrophe government
has done any most urgent actions
government needed to do but after few
days he has announced and has announced
today that he has decided to resign and
while the politicians in Latvia and and
media commentators have shown a great
high respect for the decision I can see
just in the last few minutes he's been
speaking to local journalists saying I
take moral and political responsibility
in the context of this tragedy I wonder
if that might have something to do with
the fact that the austerity measures he
introduced included abolishing the
National Building Inspectorate that
doesn't look like a very good decision
now well in 2009 government made a very
substantial cuts and very substantial
structural reforms reducing various
kinds of state agencies by 50 percent
and and of course trying to make the
duties of of these agencies as efficient
as before
are they well it wasn't just about
efficiency was it it was about wanting
to get into the eurozone which you will
do next year
surely Latvia has been seen to have done
too much too soon
well the economy in Latvia is growing
and growing quite substantially unstable
already last three years and as you said
we are expecting to be members of
eurozone starting from next January but
when when such catastrophes happen then
of course all other things probably for
politicians are not our elements but I
want to understand this every eurozone
country will want any new country
joining to be stable to have a political
leadership that it can deal with and
which can do
live a long-term stability what kind of
message do you think Latvia sent out
today with the Prime Minister and the
government going because of the collapse
of a supermarket roof well I think in
similar situations politicians have made
a similar decisions because this is
really the biggest ever catastrophe in
Latin history
and politicians have agreed to start
negotiations to start consultations
about a new government or really next
week and well this government apparently
will have a mandate and prime minister
announced he will not stand for post of
Prime Minister this government should
work until next October when we will
have a parliamentary elections so you've
got that till next October but as I
understand it the first half of 2015
Latvia will assume the rotating
presidency of the Council of the
European Union are you really in a
position to perform that presidency with
this much political instability we will
be in position to perform this
presidency because we we have we have
already we we knew that in October 14 we
will have parliamentary elections and
our government that who will perform the
presidency will be confirmed November
2014 and finally a question about the
investigation into the collapse of the
supermarket all Latvians many people
watching us around the world want to
know why those people died will this
resignation have any impact on efforts
to understand what no Prime Minister
really stressed that rule of law will be
the main principle that should be
observed also for the next government
and he will do his utmost to safeguard
this principle and I think the demand of
Latvian society to be clear who is
responsible who should hold the
responsibility and well who should hold
the criminal responsibility for for this
collapse is is so high that any
government will will obey to this demand
